content.text: We can now construct the formal proof of the Golden Rule. The proof proceeds from the consistency requirement and the irrelevance of personal identity to moral judgments.

content.title: The Golden Rule Derivation
premises: 1. ¬W_me(Do(x, me, A))          — I don't want A done to me
2. ¬W_me(Do(x, me, A)) → F(Do(x, me, A))   — What I reject is forbidden (to me)
3. F(Do(x, me, A))              — So A-to-me is forbidden (by 1,2)
4. ∀y∀z(F(Do(y, z, A)) ↔ F(Do(y', z', A)))  — Consistency: same action, same verdict
5. F(Do(me, x, A))              — So A-to-others is also forbidden (by 3,4)
content.conclusion: Therefore: ¬W_me(Do(x, me, A)) → O(¬Do(me, x, A))
content.note: If I don't want it done to me, I'm obligated not to do it to others.

content.text: The crucial move is step 4: the **consistency principle**. If action A is forbidden when done to me, it must be forbidden when done to anyone — unless there's a relevant difference. Since mere identity isn't relevant, the Golden Rule follows.

content.definition: ∀A∀x(¬W_me(Do(x, me, A)) → O(¬Do(me, x, A))). For all actions A and all persons x: if I wouldn't want A done to me, I ought not do A to x.

content.text: This is a remarkable result: a fundamental ethical principle derived from pure logic and the requirement of consistency. Ethics isn't arbitrary — it follows from the demand that we reason coherently about actions.

content.question: What is the key premise that makes the Golden Rule proof work?
options: Consistency: same action requires same moral verdict
content.explanation: The proof relies on consistency: if an action is forbidden in one case, it's forbidden in all relevantly similar cases. Combined with personal identity being irrelevant, this yields the Golden Rule.
